DOC.HEAD: Doctor Gets Probation and Community Service For Infanticide
DOC.TEXT: An obstetrician convicted of infanticide after witnesses said he let an aborted fetus die was placed on three years' probation today and ordered to perform 300 hours of community service. Dr. Joseph Melnick, 66, was found guilty in a non-jury trial in June, the first criminal prosecution under Pennsylvania's 1974 abortion law, which requires doctors to do what they can if they remove a living fetus. Common Pleas Judge Lynn Abraham heeded Melnick's plea for leniency, calling what he did a ``criminal mistake'' for which neither jail nor a heavy fine was appropriate. She also said she had no intention of making an example of him. The mistake, the judge said, was that the doctor performed an abortion on a teen-ager in her eighth month of pregnancy. The doctor said he had been told she was in her fourth or fifth month. State law prohibits most abortions after six months, but Melnick was not charged with performing an illegal abortion. ``I am very sorry that this unfortunate incident occurred,'' Melnick told the judge. ``Please do not judge me by this one incident alone.'' The judge ordered Melnick perform his community service in medical facilities. He could have received 3{ to 7 years in prison. Assistant District Attorney David Webb had asked for a jail term and a fin. Witnesses, including nurses at West Park Hospital, where the 1984 abortion on a 13-year-old was performed, had said that the fetus survived about 90 minutes and moved and gasped but that Melnick ordered that no care be given. Melnick contended the 3-pound, 9-ounce girl was stillborn. The doctor is still practicing. State licensing authorities are expected to take up the case. Defense attorney Richard Sprague said he would appeal on grounds the verdict was not justified by the evidence. Melnick originally was charged with murder, but the charge was dismissed on grounds of insufficient evidence, and the abortion law was invoked.
